div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. div.head: TRADE OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Commenting on the business methods followed by British tradesman in Alexandria Mi Grieg, acting Consul, says in his consular report. The British origin of goods is, here as elsewhere, an accepted guaranteed of merit, and not a few critics in this country aver that British manufacturers might oven enhance their success, advocating (I) the adoption of the metric system ; (2) the frequent visits of commercial travellers , (3) general adaptability for local requirements , (4) the quotation of prices in c.i.f. or as other terms required . (5) the reduction o.bstacles so far us possible ; (6) the acceptance of small initial orders ; (1) accurate adherence to specifications . (H) great care and punctuality in the packing and delivery of goods . and v'Jy subject to due precautions, longer credits It is impossible here to do more than comment on u few of these items of advice. As regards the fourth mentioned, whilst as a general rule nl! quota tions should be c i.f. Alexandria, since those terms only are accepted hy native pur chaserx, sellers should l>e prepared to quote their prices in any other terms desired. One of the secrets of the mu inconsiderable progress made by Uermany in Egyptian and other commercial eiroles lies in tho delivery of goods “free into customers' stores." Knowing without further effort the total cost of consignments, the buyer is thereby spared the labourions calculation of inciden t«l expenses It would be especially easy in the case of Egypt for manufacturers fa> quote prices “franco domicile," for the eus toms require un almost uniform duty ol 8 percent as colorem. As regards the eighth item of advice, tho methods of packing wares have from time to time been eriti cised. It is said that lug crates are pro ferable lo boxes, especially for glass, lor the latter are thrown from place to place with scanty ceremony by the native earner h the docks Freights would be economise! if bulky goods, such as furniture, were pa eked in numbered parts. As regards the ninth item of advice—the length of cred.i to be given must always remain a quest,.,r, for each manufacturer to decide accord in, to circumstances. Longer credit is cerfam.l. given—especially by Continental manufu- i,, rent—here than in most countries, mid n , tiers are guided in the quotation of 11,.- r prices by the anticipation of delayed payment It need scarcely be said that where H i- proposed to give long credits, the appointim-n' of a trustworthy agent is essential. The Briri-i Chamber of Commerce undertakes to pmvid- its raenbere with such, and the following hi, quoted fromacircular issued by that institut may be of interest “The Chamber lav- • out to procure reliable agents for innnufu. i„r.-i by putting the latter in touch with -unnl..- houses here. The importance of tin- w..n. obvious, since pratically everything dep. upon the home Hiui having u tni-r«,,r-1,. representative”. Manufacturers unable to procure ,-i,i| reliable agents should send out twice n, u,.. year commercial travellers with aluindni.’ supplies'of pattenis or samples and coloured catalogues. Even linns enjoying i|„ services of agents should send such travcllci at least once a year to visit clients, stud) tlu-ir and otherwise develop their tn*.|>- Prench, a knowledge of Arabic, Italian or Greek would IK* advantageous fa. then. Continental firms engaged in the manufacture of some identical commodity sometimes shni- the services of a capable commercial traveller, and the system is said to give satiRfnofa.n results. In connection with the import trade, it is felt in commercial circles here that in .t country wliere long credits are a necessim evil, the circumspection practised by the eourts in protecting debtors against creditor- should be even greater than elsewhere, and the law of judicial liquidation, once undoubted!: harsh towards certain classes of debtors, i- said to incline at present towards lenien. ) For until March 26, 1900 it was in the power of a creditor, however insignificant might be his share in the total intere-i- involved, to reject tho proposals of an u. solvent debtor, even if these were favoural. ly regarded by the creditors most vilsllv interested, and so to leave no option but bankruptcy to persous unfortunate but possibly honest. In 1900 a provision known as the Concordat Préventif, akin in spirit to Sect. 3 of our Bankruptcy Act of |K9u. was introduced into the Civil Code of Egypt and it became possible for an insolvent del. toi, proved to the satisfaction of the court to have been unfortunate and guiltless .it lishonesty, to claim the sanction of law f..r his proposals if formally accepted by a um jority of creditors representing three-quur tors of the total interests involved, to com pel the acquiescence of the dissenting few. and thus to escape the taint of bankruptcy * Such a composition was open to obvious abuses on the part of unscrupulous persons, ami subsequently changes were introduced with a view to enabling judge and creditors fa. form their decisions in the light of the large-1 possible measure of reliable information ILS !■> the debtor’s morality and affairs, and to ensiir ing the conscientious execution of compositions vouchsafed. But although the changes intro dneed did something to check some obvious abuses, others more subtle have survived to the detriment of the commercial community Further changes have indeedfrom time to time been suggested by various mercantile associa tions tending fa. lirait the privileges of the Concordat to debtors able to pay a minimum dividend of .00 or 60 per cent, of their total liabilities, to pay such dividend within a limit od space of time, and to provide adeqmire guarantees of payment. These suggestions have not, however, been adopted- The frequency of bankruptcies an.I the many abuses of the Concordat have led r.. the formation by the Importers’ Association, on the invitation of importers of Manchester piece-goods, of a "Committee for the protection of creditors," ensuring to its members by com bined and enlightened action greater a.I vantages, both morally and substantially, than could result from private negotiations, to., often of a semi-frudulent nature, with the debtor or third parties. The committee shoul l be-especially helpful to the many whose claim- on estates are small, and who might, in isolated action, have to choose between sacrificing their interests and spending in the attempt I" recover them a sum disproportionate to tlnur value. The committee, formed us it wit' a! tic instance of importers of Manchester piece goods, merits the attention of British maim facturera and traders , the cast of membership is trilling, and correspondence can lie conducted by letter. During the six months of it' existence the committee lias done good work.

div.head: Fire at Kom el Dik
div.p: At five o'clock yesterday morning, the watchman of the central fire-brigade station noticed that a fire had broken ont on the top floor of a house at Kom el Dik. The alarm given ,the tire-brigade at once got to work, blit owing to the feeble water pressure they were unable to work with any effect until two steamers hail arrived. The fire was confined to the room in which the outbreak occurred, the contenta of w liich have been totally destroyed. The damages have not yet been esliinnted and the cause of the fire is unknown.

div.head: "TO SEE WITH OTHER EYES."
div.p: MR. MITCHELL INNES' PAMPHLET
Commenting npon the pamphlet for private circulation written by Mr. Mitchell Innés, to which we referred some time ago, the “Speota- tor" says :—

It is an essay written by an Englishman, a high Egyptian offioial, who has been connected with Egypt during the greater part of Lord Cromer’s administration. Wo wish that this essay—which we truBt tho author will soon give to a wider public—could be read by those foolish persons who imagine that the desire of every British offioial in Egypt when he sees a native is to fly at him with kioks and ourses, or who fanoy that because it was necessary to do justice, and stem justice, to the brntal ruffians who murdered British officers at Denshawi and plundered their bodies, Englishmen in Egypt generally believe that the proper way to govern natives is .to terrorise them. The writer of the essay urges upon the young Englishmen who enter the public service in; Egypt the necessity of showing kindness and sympathy to the Egyptians, and of not drawing an indictment against a whole people, or believing that because some Egyptians are cowardly and untruthful intriguers, therefore the native population as a whole is to be considered to possess those vices. Though we do not agree with certain things In the essay, and though we think that the writer does not state quite definitely enough the superiority of the British race, the fault there is, we admit, on the right side. The facte against the belief in equality between the Oriental and the Anglo- Saxon, judgiiig not by individuals but by the whole, are so strong that we are not in the least afraid of their ever being forgotten in Egypt or in India. As we have said above, if tho races were really equal in moral, why lias not the Oriental developed institutions like, or superior to, our own Î—a question certainly not unfair considering the fact that he has had three times the anioumt of time in which to do it. This, however, is a minor matter. Whether wo think them inferior or equal, we are entirely at one with the writer of the essay in holding that our superiority is to be shown by treating the natives with the utmost kindness, consideration, and jnstico. The more we believe that we have the giant’s strength, the more clear is it that it is "tyrannous to use it like a giant." If the Englishman maintains true dignity, true self-respect, and a true sense of justice, he will never go wrong with the natives, and the question of equality can be left to settle itself. What our young administrators have to learn is, in effect, how to inspire the true sense of superiority. That will be not by violence when they are opposed, or by showing contempt for those who differ from them, but by doing the very opposito of what the nalivo. himself does when he is angry or excited. If for no other reason than that it is not a conspicuous native virtue, self-control should be tlie cardinal virtue practised by the Briton.

It must not be supposed that because the Englishman who has written the little work with which we are dealing gives such useful warning and advice to his younger colleagues, he therefore suggests that thoy are in any great or speciul need of it, or that the British, of all men of the white race, require such advice. The exact opposite is, ot course, the truth, as no doubt .he would lie tho first to acknowledge. We may not be perfect in our dealings with natives, but without question we treat them far better than the Frenchman, the German, or even the American does. Again, it murt-not bo sup|>ased that the writer of the pamphlet advocates an unwise assimilation of Europeans nnd natives. To quote his own words, “I do not advocate unnecessary intercourse with them. Only that that which is necessary and right in the execution of our duty should be characterised by kindness." He onds by dwelling upon the importance of acquiring the power to put onesolf in another’s place and "to see with others’ eyes." Until wo liave attained to that, he tells us, we have not mounted far up the ladder which leads to success in governing. The qualities that he preaches, lie is quite right in declaring, imply no want of strength or character. “Firmness is the twin brother of gentleness, déterminât^) and patience go hand in hand, and a clear recognition of the defects of a people is compatible ' with love of them.” These, indeed, are Imperial qualities, and worthy of those whom “fate and the ocean and some fostering star” hAve made a democracy which rules not only itself but others.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Tons les préparatifs ont été faits pour le grand bal de ce soir. La direction du Casino ainsi que les Messieurs chargés de conduire le cotillon feront tous leurs efforts, nous en sommes certains, pour nous donner la plus belle fête do la saison.
L’ouverture du bal, qui sera donné dans la grande sallo des fêtes, aura lieu à 10 heures 1/4 et le cotillon commencera à 11 heures 30.

Au programme qui sera exécuté demain matin à 11 heures, nous sommes heureux de voir figurer deux morceaux entièrement nouveaux, qui sont: Les scènes Alsaciennes de Massenet et la célèbre Suite Espana de Chabrie.
A 5 h. 80 de l’après-midi, pour le concert vocal et in-trumental, nous aurons aussi le plaisir d’entendre la finale du 3me acte de l’Er- nnni tout entière, chantée par les trois artistes.
Le programme du cinématographe sera de même des plus intéressants.
Le prix d’entrée reste toujours de P.T. 5.

div.head: THE NATIONALIST CHAMELEON.
div.p: "MODERATES" IN LONDON.
(FROM "AL WATAN.")

The Nationalist journalists who are nowin Ixmdon have supplied their oountrymen with a new subject for jest and laughter by their grotesque inainoerity and their strange conciliatory tone. Among Englishmen these Egyptian Nationaliste gave expression to the most friendlyJsehngs and appeared to ask fpr nothing distasteful to English palates. In Egypt they go beyond all limits in inoiting the lower classes to rise against England and shew their hatred in a thousand ways.

Hafiz Awad is now in London under a false mask. Like tire chameleon ho has changed his colour to suit his surroundings ; but he can deceive only a few simple hearted Radicals whose deception will not interfere with the course of our Administration- In Egypt this Nationalist chameleon makes it his duty to publish every day revolutionary articles or poems calling upon his readers to contribute to the daily agitation in the name of Denshwai. In England he calls himself a friend and an ardent reformer,! Here he objects to all forms of genuine reform on the ground that such reforms touch the sacred rights of the Sultan or the Khedive. Here he preaches pan-Islamistn and the suzerainty of the Sultan; he even fights the battle of Turkey against his own country as he and his friends always do whenever a move is signalled from Constantinople. In England he dreads a return of the Tnrkish. rulo and thinks that tho greatest moment for Egypt was when Mohamed Ali freed it from the Turkish yoke ! Here bis only subject is a dishonest criticism of England's work in Egypt, India, and elsewhere, the translation of anything likely to make new enemies to England among his readers ; he never gives publicity to a word against Turkey and her Government In England he is entirely different and his skin changea colour in order to deceive English eyes I Here he is the most violent agitator ip the cause of absolute independence, immediate evacuation, and up-to-date parliamentary institutions In England he accepts the British occupation and the British control (Many thanks from merrie England) asking for the simplest association in certa'iu local affairs.

This is how the Nationalist chameleon tries to deceive England by a change of colour. But will the deception last ? Will those in authority believe in the new colour of the Nationalist and take him into serious consideration ? We have no doubt that the British authorities are better informed than these chameleons appear to think, and that nothing will deceive them as long as the Nationalist Press goes hand in hand with the high source of this anti English agitation, the source of the chameleou policy which our petty scribes believe to he the essence of wisdom and which they have followod with such poor results.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: MR. DUDLEY ALDERSON.

We greatly regret to report the sudden death of Mr. Dudley Alderson, a son of Mr. G.JL—AWerson, who is so well-known and so popular among all classes in Alexandria. Telegraphing this morning, our Zagazig correspondent says :—“Mr. Alderson, of the Agricultural Bank, was found dead in a carriage of the morning local train from Hehia to Zagazig on arrival of the train at the latter station. Life was extinct and the body was conveyed to the hospital by the police’ officials.”
We beg to offer our sincere condolences to Mr. G. B. Alderson and the relations of the deceased
MR. ANDRE PANGALO.

A telegram from Athens announces the death of M. André Pangalo, who was till lately councillor 'of tho Court of Appeal of this city. The deceased came to Egypt in 188G as judge of the Mixed Tribunals, and last year replaced M. Antonindis as councillor. He resigned last July owing to ill-health, and returned to Greece a few weeks ago. The news ot his death

div.head: THE CROMER MEMORIAL
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir,—Referring to your issue of the25th ulto. in which it is stated that "l ,000 Circulars were iasued by Mr. Moss to British residents in Alexandria, that of these 180 were returned through the Dead Letter Office, therefore, of the 1,000, 870 were received by the British Colony.” What evidence is there that 870 circulars were received I I for one did not receive a circular, (that may have been the fault of my office people). I do not know when the circulars were sent out, but I fanoy tnhç it must have been after the 1st of May last when people had begun to leavo fortliesinnmer.'If so, I would respectfully suggest that Mr. Moss might renew his laudable efforts by the issue of a second lot of circulars in November next, by which time I venture to think that he will get a good many more than 29 replies.

div.head: TRADE OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: EXPORTS AND IMPORTS

The increasing disproportion between exports and importa is striking, Baya Mr. Grieg in his consular report With the rapidly-increasing population of Alexandria, estimated, pending the approaching oensus, at 408,000 souls, building operations continue with unabated aotivity. During the past year 985 new houses were actually completed, as against 686 in 1906 and 182 in 1901, whilst 2,788 were taken in hand as against 1,912 in 1905 and 766 in 1901. In connection with this work it may be obseived that there has been a steady increase in the prioe of stone for building, for the quarries near the town are becoming exhausted, and material bas to be sought further afield, a circumstance which led to the formation of companies for the manufacture of sand-bricks. The prioe of labour which has risen daring the last few years with the general increase in rents and the prioe# of all commodities, maintains its level with little fluctuation. The price of land in Alexandria, high as it is, is not considered exaggerated. The value of a square pic (about 16} square yards) near the Bourse is estimated at 25À to 30/., and even ih the veriest slums it would be difficult to find land for less than 2/ per square pic.

An extension of the tramways, which already knit up the eastern suburbs of Alexandria, to Dekhela, a point some 12 miles westward, where it is proposed to build a casino and summer residences—is under consideration. It is further proposed to carry the lines along tho quays and to the NouzhaPublio Gardens, which liave recently been renôvated by the Municipality. Indeed the latter is doing much to improve the town and the suburbs, ' and the work of laying down a promenade along the sea-front to Mustapha, a suburb some 3 miles to the east of Alexandria, is shortly to be begun, and should be completed within two two or three years. A project, likely to be carried out in three or four years, is the construction of a new passonger station for the Egyptian State railways. The Alexandria Water Company has now carried to all the eastern suburbs of the town it# supply ot water. The total value of the import# to Alexandria during the year 1906 was 21,520,353/.R. as against 19,066,3881.E- in 1905, representing an increase ot 2,454,016/.E., whereas the average yearly increase during the period 1901-06 waa 1,421,916/E.

There has been an appreciable increase in import# from the United Kingdom and the colonies, which together claim 37 per cent, of the total import# and 36 per cent of the increase during 1906. The increase of import# from the United Kingdom in 1906 was more than double ot the average yearly increase in the period 1901-05. Whilst (hero has been a decrease in imports from the British Mediterranean possessions, whose average yearly increase during the period 1901-05 was 21,338 LE., the increase of activity in import# from the British Far Eastern possessions (inoludir.g Canada) contrasts with their fall-off during the period 1901-05. Relatively to their respective shares in the import trade, Belgium, Germany and Franco (including Algeria) claim the largest proportions of tho increase.

Thus, the increase realised by Belgium daring the past year was 387,206 L.E., whereas the average yearly increase for the period 1901-05 was 81,260 LE. Her share in the total imports to Alexandria was 5 per cent, as against 4 per cent during the period 1901-05, and her share in the inorease of the past year is 16 per cent Imports from Germany have increased by 348,602 L.R., whereas their average yearly increaso during the period 1901-05 was 104,173 L.E. Germany’s share of the import# to Alexandria which fell to 5 per ceut in 1905, again reached 6 percept during 1906. The increase in import# from France (including Algeria) during the past year amounted to 402,423 LE., whereas the average yearly increaso for tho period 1901-05 was 220,028 LE. America and Greece liave increased their shares of the import# from 2 to 3 per cent, and 1 ti 2 per cent respectively. The shares of Austria-Hungary, Italy and Ruasia liave fallen from 8 to 7 per cent. 6 to 5 per cent, nnd 4 to 2 per cent, respectively.

By far the most conspicuous increase during the past year has been in the category of metals ami machinery. Next come chemicals and pliarmaceutical substances (including chemical manure), coal, and wood (including furniture), huilding materials, and groceries The demand for leather and leather goods, paper and books, spirit#, beer and wine has likewise increased. Textiles have not increased in the same marked pro* portions as during the previous five years

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr.P.W. Marchet is staying at Filey, Yorkshire

By the retirement of Brevet-Colonel LSrd Edward Ceeil, D.S.O, Under-Seoretary of 8tate for Finance in the Egyptian Government, the Brigade of Guards loses the services of an experienced and highly-qualified officer. He is the fourth son of ths late Marquis of Salisbury, and entered the Grenadier Guards as a Seoond Lieutenant fro* the Militia in 1887, subsequently beooming Aided e-Camp to Visoonnt Wolseley while commanding the forces in Ireland. On the formation of the Dongola expedition he joined Viscount Kitchener’s staff, and waa present at the-enfcage- ment at Pirket and the operations at Hafir, for which he was mentioned in despatches, received a medal with three olasps, the fourth class of the Medijidie, and the brevet rank of hiajor. In 1897 he was selected to aoeom pany the Mission to Abyssinia, and was decorated by King Menelik with the third claas of the Star of Ethiopia. During the final campaign against the Mahdi, Lord Edward Cecil again officiated on the staff of Lord Kitchener, and tort part in the battles of Atbara and Khartoum; being further recognised in despatches and awarded the Distinguished Service Order. In the repent South African War he went through the defence of Mafeking. On retaining to Egypt from Sonth Africa he was appointed Agent- General of the Sudan Government and Direotor of Intelligence at Cairo, and subsequently Under-Secretary of War.
Captain Stanley Flower has returned to Cairo from his annual holiday.
Mr. H. A. Davidson lui# resigned the management of the Cairo branch of the Bank of Egypt The management will be carried on temporarily by Mr. L Biddulph and Mr. M. J. Temple.

div.head: A NEW PAPYRUS
div.p: Among the many portions of written papyri discovered by M. Jouguet at Ghoran in the Fayoura, and which were preserved beoanse used for stiffening thecartonago of mammy cases, is one which forms the first of the new work "Papyrus Grecs publiées par le section Papyrologique de l’Univèrsité de Lille.” This manuscript is more complete than usual with such pieces measuring 16 by 81 centimetres, and is written upon both sides. Although as literature it is of no interest, it’is of much value for the cadastral mensuration at the time of the Ptolemies for it contains apian displaying four canals and the irrigation dykes upon a farm in the Fayoum and the wholfl^^ surface of a given area is marked out into’4(F> equal sized plots. Because of this, it give# us for the first time the corroot dimensions of the old Greek surface measure, called Naubion, and also, indirectly, of another, the Aiolion, Some 30 lines of the text and the whole of the diagram of the works ore perfectly preserved, and the statements in the document supply information as to the sums paid in winter and summer for the work necessary to keep in good’ order the arrangements for irrigating, and indicate a pian for such works as were then carried out for the purpose. The style of the writiug is of the third century B.C. and as the papyrus bears the date of year 27 of‘some Lagid monarch we know it must have been written under Ptolemy Philadelphn# in, 268/9 B.C. The month being given as Phaophi, dates it definitely as November or December of 259 B.C.

The contents show that work prolonged into the Bpring or hot season was better paid tor than in the winter, probably heeaase of the heat At the end of the papyrus the Inspector, whose memoranda it embodies and whose name appears to liave been Apollonius, states that ho left the site of the worts on the 7th day of Athyr and went by water to a post called a Phylake, a new name for an officials’ quarters in the Fayoum, though a frequent one in the Hcrinopolito nome. From the Phylake he proceeded to Tonphis, a town known from the Rniiier papyri, at Vienna, thence to tho "Town of the Syrians” which is mentioned in the Petrie Papyri, and another papyrus in London, finally arriving at Ptolemais, bnt there were so many cities of that name in the Fayoum it is difficult to say which is intended. Near to the village of the Syrians was Ptolemais Néa, but as Apolloniqa says he was near (o the Labyrinth it may be Ptolemais Hormon or Ptolemais Euegeti». Wpally he rep-wta his arrival at ?the city” tat does not tall *. its name. Later tlie dimensions of. the New* bion which occuis again in papyrus No. 669 of Roman to be somewhat larger than in the papyrus at Lille, dating from four centnrils earlier ; but perhaps the later doonmeot, now tfcft we have the clear description of these agrarian measures from Ghoran, may be more correctly interpreted

div.head: TELEGRAMS
THE SUBJUGATION OF CASABLANCA.
div.p: EUROPEAN QUARTERS BOMBARDED.
LOOTING AT MOGADOR
Paris, August 9.

Official telegrams give mostgraphio descrip tione of the defenoa • of the Consulate quarter of Casablanca. The attacks of the tribesmen culminated in a great onslaught on the morning of the 7th instant Four oruisera arrived just in time to relieve the defender» who were practically exhausted. The French had seven killed and two officers and ten men wounded. The Spaniards also had casualties. The French reinforcements camped outside tire town and vigorously repulsed an attack by 6000 tribesmen. The town has been practically wiped out. The refugees have returned to land and order has been restored.

TANOTER, August 9. The latest advices seem to show that the French were seriously mistaken in landing parties before a large foroe was available. The tribesmen seised the opportunity to loot whole quarters of the town and maintained a furiohs fusillade on the French Consulate, where there were many refugees. It was largely the bômbardmônt by the Galiléo that saved the Consulate'from capture. A steamer has left here hastily for Milzagan in response to a wireless telegram from the British Consul. (Reuter)
MOOADOR, Angust 9. The tribes have plundered Cape Juby, killing mid capturing several soldiers. (Havas)
PARIS, August 9. The European press approves of the French policy.''

CASABLANCA, August 9. The 'town is in ruind and présenta a most lamentable scene, as the European quarter has had to be bombarded. The French and Spanish marines displayed great heroism in defending the Consulates until the arrival of the reinforcements. The refugees are returning in parties. ( Havas )
TANGIER, Aogust 9. Thé bombardment of Casablanca lasted for 48 hdüte. It is stated that 1000 Moors have been killed or wounded. -y (Reuter
TANOIBR, August 9. The branch of the 8tato Bank turn been sacked by Moors and 60,000 pesetas stolen.(A)

div.head: THE PERSIAN DISTURBANCES
div.p: FIGHT WITH THE TURKS.

CONSTANTINOPLE, August 9. According to the Turkish version, the Persian Commander Medjiss Sultana with regulars, 1000 irtegnlais, and 400 Armenian revolutionaries were preparing to attack the disputed frontier town at Mergovar, and for that reason the Turks summoned reinforcements from Van: The Persian attaok was subsequently repulsed with heavy loss Medjla» Sultana states that Be went to neighbourhood of Metgovar to pursue the murderers of an American miasiotiary nnd to chAstW the Knrdish brigands. The Turkish commander thereupon advanced info Persian territory and ordered Medjiss Sultana to evacuate the district within three hours. At the expiry of the term - bombarded the camp, compelling the Persians to retreat. (R.)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT

London, July 25. The 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, recently stationed at Cairo on temporary duty, has been placed tinder orders to leave Malta for India in November. The battalion expected to get a home station ip.stead of going to India. Another surprise is the ordering of the 3rd Battalion Worcestershire Regiment from Aldershot to South Africa. Lieutenant the Honourable M. St A. St John, King’s Own Scottish Borderers, who is borne1 on Hie strength of thé 1st Battalion, has l>een placed on temporary half pay owing to had health. Major A. Sutherland, Argyll and Sufliérland Highlanders, on promotion to substantive field rank in his own regiment remains with the Khedive’s Army. He is employed in command of the troop in the Berber District.

1/ondon, July 31st- Major C.H. Leveson, 18th Hussan, the next senior officer of tha cavalry of the Khedive's army since the retirement of Lieutenant Colonel W.H. Ferme, of the Bays, learned his soldiering in the rough school of practical service during four campaigns, in the course of which he found himself in more than one tight! corner. Beginning his career in the lBtlr Hussars in 1880, ho saw his first active service' in the Chitral Relief Expedition, 1895 (medal with clasp); and next in the North‘West Frontier campaign which followed m 1897-98 (two olaspa). He joined the West African Regiment in 1899, and thus was not in'the early phases of the South-Afriean War, and the defence of Ladysmith, in which the 18th was prominently engaged, but had a turn through thé Ashanti Expedition, 1900 (medal with olasp). Ho joined the 18th in the field in 1901, and went through the operations in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony, and on the Zulnland frontier of Natal, in the course of wliioli ho was severely wounded. Forhis services ho was mentioned in despatches, and nwanfed lhe*Qiteen’s medal with two clasps. Taking service with the Khedive’s troops in Fobrnary, 1908, he has proved his Admirable capacity not only as a regiment officer but as an administrative officer.

Three subalterns of the King’s Own Scottish Borderers, Lieutenant H.W. Todhnnter, Assistant Instructor at the School of Musketry, Hythe ; Lieutenant C.F. Kennedy, adjutant of the 1st Battalion, Cairo, and ' Lieutenant B.J.B. Coulson, of the latter battalion, have just been promoted captains, and the first named two lmve been seconded in their respective appointments. Captain Todhunter got his first commission in 1898, and served with the 1st Battalion in the operations in Orange Free State, the .fights at Fonrdeberg, Poplar Grove, Karroo Siding, Vet . River ami Zand River, operations in the Transvaal, the actions near Johannesburg, Pretoria, and at various scraps east and west of Pretoria (mentioned in desjatches Queen’s medal with three clasps, King’s medal with two clasps). Captain Kennedy joined the Bordorers in 1899, and hail a turn of service with the Mounted Infantry in the above named actions, in addition to the battle of Diamond Hill, and the lesser affairs in Orange River Colony, Capo Colony and the Transvaal (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with four clasps and King's medal with two clasps). Captain Conlson was also with the Mounted Infantry, but had the liaril luck of being knocked out of action at Karrce Siding bya dangerous wound, after having come through the fighting at Puardoborg, and Zand River (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with two clasps). These are the first company promotions in the Borderers since December of last year.

Second Lieutenant C.B.R. Hoey, 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Alexandria, tins been promoted lieutenaut: ami also Second Lieutenant .1. R Hnrtley, 2nd Battalion King's ^wn Scottish Borderers. Lieutenant Ilooy got his first commission in 1902, in time to share in the latter three months fighting in the Transvaal, (Queen’s medal with four clasps)

Major R C. Stevenson, Royal Garrison Artillciy, commanding No- 22 Company, Leith, has been transferred to No. 2 Company, Cuiro. Miyor Stevenson has served in the Royal Regiment since July, 1882, was promoted captain in 1891, and major in 1900. He has not seen any war service.
The Inniskilling Dragoons are to ho kopt nt their present establishment of three service squadrons and a resorve squadron. Thé latter at home.

A year from now, the command of tho Inniskilling .will fall vacant in the usual course. The command should go to Major F. A. B. Fryer, the second in command, jmd the vacant majority in that case to Captain W. H. King, who is employed with the Egyptian Army.

div.head: A HANDBOOK OF EGYPTIAN RELIGION
div.p: BT ADOLF ERXAN. (Constable & Co.) (ConRnUed.) Very odd^are Fret. Erman’s ideas on magic, which he here states to be “a barbar- rons offshoot (A uswuchs) of religion," thereby ignoring utterly the rival thehries that it is the earliest form, of all religion, or that magic aud religion aie inséparable twins which came into being nt the- same time and have always existed together. He thinks that in the Fifth-Dynasty the magioa ideas, according to which the representations of slaves at . weak, of food, and of pastimes in tho paintings of the tombs were . supposed to operate for the benefit of the dead, gave- way to artistic .and decorative nhtions, and thAt these pictures were then made to please the relations who gotbored in the tombs, from time to time to celebrate tho funeral feasts. But this surely must be erroneous. Magical ideas; so far from, dyeing out, claimed an ever-inoreasinq part in the religtous ideas of the .Egyptians, and under'that Middle'Kingdom which Prof. Erinan considers the classic period, the resentntions in question were no longer _ rely painted, but carved in the round, so underlying idea here seems to have been exactly'the same as that which led malevolent magicians to make wax imaged of thosé they wished to injure, a practice exemplified in the oolebrated Palace Conspiracy of the Nineteenth Dyhaaty. Bilt perhaps the greatest inversion of facts to fit the author's theories occurs in Prof. Erman's constant? resort to punning or assonance as a link betwen unrelated words. Thus he tells us that the legend tbat(men were created from the- tears of the gods LA derived from the fact tha.t remyet means “tears” and romet “mankind" ; that the moon was created by Ra in a speech where he told the moon-god tliat he would make him “embrace the heavens with his beauty” because yooh yonh means “embrace” and yooh “create" ; and that the ibis became the bird of Thoth because Ra told him he would send him to those greater than himself, hob meaning “send” and hibt “ibis" This is tho very înwlsuiimior madness of etymology. Later ages do indeed some times try to explain forgntteu derivations by puns, as in the celebrated case of Stanton (Stand to ’un !) Harcourt : but then the pnn is based on tlifl similarity of sound, nnd not on that of appearance. The tiling that chiefly strikes our ears in the spoken word is the vowel, and hib (pronounced heel) is not in the least like hob nntil wo begin to write it, Berlin fashion, in consonants only. Thus there can never liato been any likeness to Egyptian ears between yonh and yooh, remyet and romet ; and the equivalence of these jwirs of words can only be substantiated by the supposition that the Egyptians hnd nntioipat od Prof. Ennans theory that tho vowels in their language oould be left to the imagination. Merely to state such a proposition is to show its absurdity.

It is pleasant to turn from these vagaries ol the learned to the pointa in which we can praise. Prof. Erman’s work. For more than thirty years he teels us he lias studied the monuments of Egyptian religion, and the conclusions at which so able a scholar has arrived os the result of this study must always be worth attention. In his attribution of the idea of the king’s divinity and of tho Osiri- legend to the earliest ages of Egypt, he i> almost certainly correct -, as ho is in his assertion that alchemy and horoscope-casting were unknown to the Egyptians before tho influx o! Greek learning Whether ho is right in suppos ing tluit the sem priest at. the funeral actually played the part of the dead, and that the king ship of Osiris over the other world roarkci. a chango of religious ideas, is more open t- question ; but in liotli cases, as in many others that that could be named, Prof. Ennau!a_theories are strongly-founded, and entitled to every respect. The book is an excellent guide to tho rich Egyptian Museum of Berlin, nnd, as we said in our first notice, specially valuable to English readers ns giving them representations of inonuincnD with which they have small opportunities ol making themselves acquainted. Why tin English translator should have omitted any ot these, as she has done, is hard to say ; but m fault can bo found with tho substitution in the present volume of examples from Mr. Hiltoi Price's collection for the similar, but less perfect monuments at Berlin. Mr. Griffith, in n characteristic Preface, asserts that “Prof Erman is the first to present the Egyptian religion in . historical perspective," thereby ignoring tho fact that this is the distinguishing feature in the works of M. Maspero, Prof. Wiedemann, and Dr. Budge ; nor do wo find that tho special preface which his panegyrist claims that Dr. Efraan has written for the English edition differs one jot from that of the Gorman original. For the rest, the translation adequately represents tho sense of the author, and the illustrations are well reproduced. We have noticed only one misprint

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

Saiii qii’ièy ait eu quoi que ce srtit d'extraordinaire, la semaine qui vient de finir n été, (buis sim ensemble, et /du moins dnns sa dernière partie, un peu meilleure que la précédente anus le rapport de l'notivité. Certes, les tmiiMiotions sont loin d'avoir été nombreuses, mais après le marasme auquel nous avions fini, pour ainsi dire, par nous habituer, les quelques opérations qui se sont fuites ces jours-ci ont suffi pour donner un semblant d'activité au marché.' Quant à la marche des prix et à l'ordre dans lequel les changements se sont succédés, le tout a procédé presque de la même façon que la huitaine d'avant, aveu cette seule différence que la finale a peut-être été'plus -atisfaisnnte. Mais, n’anticipons pas et procédons pur ordre

Ordre an -rapport du Bureau (l’Agriculture de Washington et à lu hausse provoquée par -on Hi , connue condition de la plante, la séance de Samedi a été très ferme et les prix sont maintemis il leur niveau de lu veille, mais eu ce qai concerne 1 animation, c'ast à peine si I.ni peut dire que trois à quatre affaires ont eu lieu comme affirmation de l’existence de noire marché aux contrats

la- fait est que pendant presque tout le lumps tout le momie était loin de la corbeille, un point que l’on aurait dit'que nous étions en plein jour férié ; heureusement que cette séance n'a duré que de 10 heures à midi

Quoique mauvaise après tout* la matinée eu question ne laissait nullement entrevoir la faiblesse qui s'est dessinée Mardi à lu reprise des affaires, après le chômage de Lundi à l'occasion du Bank Holiday d'Août en Angleterre, et qui nous a valu un recul de 3/8 de tallnri sur la cote du Novembre. Ce revirement inattendu, uvcc une Amérique des plus fermes el des exjiortations faisant présager dès le dél.ut nue semaine de beaucoup supérieure à ce point de vue à tons les pronostics, a été causé simplement par l’abondance de l’offre lomliant à un moment oii les acheteurs n'étaient guère disposés à opérer, et par les manœuvres liatssières de quelques intéressés (pii ont cru devoir profiter de la circonstance pour peser sur la situation dans le sens qui leur convenait.

Par sa façon de se cjnhporter, le marché venait de nous prouver qu'il n'y nvait pas jHissibilité de compter sur la spéculation nu cas où l’on serait tenté de faire un mouvement quelconque.; mais malgré cette impression on considérait que les choses avaient été trop loin et trop vite et la preuve en est qu'après les premières escarmouches du lendemain qui firent fléchir le Novembre à 20 tallnris vendeurs; la tendance changea de nouveau pour le mieux sur une demande surgie tout-à-coup et que d’aucuns ont voulu attribuer au commerce d’exportation, tandis qu’en réalité il s'agissait peut-être de rachats pour compte du découvert.

Quoi qu’il en soit, ln fermeté n’a fait que s’accentuer depuis lors, pour nous faire finir aujourd'hui sur la cote de 20 3/8 pour le Novembre, ce. qui réduit à 1/1C la perte subie depuis Vendredi donner. Ce n’est sûrement pas là le résultat que légitimement nu. aurait pu espérer, tuais comme reprise après la forte chute de Mardi, ce n’est pas « dédaigner du tout

Toutefois, cette tenue plus ou moins satisfaisante, suivant le point de vue auquel ■ ni se place pour l’envisager, est restée confinée à la nouvelle récolte seule, car pour ce qui est lie l’Août, las choses?ont eu une allure qui n énormément laissé à désirer: I1 échéance en question a fini à 19 7/8, soit en baisse de 3/8 de tallafi pour In semaine, mais ce qui est incontestable c’est qu'hier des »lliiires ont été faites h 19 5/8 et que 1“ cote do 19 7/8 est purement nominale.

Il y a peut être quelque chose de surprenant à voir que le commerce, à ces eonditions,mon ire quand même de la réserve, surtout qu’il ne se pusse presque pas de journée sans qn'iqie vente sur Août ou Septembre se fasse pour I Europe. A cola il y a deux explications : nos Exportateurs avant de faire de nouveaux achats cherchent à se débarrasser. de ce qu'ils ont, tandis que d'autre jvart le flottant eu vieille récolte est si réduit, 10 à 12,000 cantnrs en dil on, qu'il ne jiciil donner lieu à un d’affaires régulier. l)u reste, d'ici quel- ,l"Ç's jours ou ueutendni plus parler de I Août.

Lu nouvelle recolle, par contre, continue ù n>-pus jouir des sympathies de la consomma- iion. on espère néanmoins nu réveil des nllnires pour la prochaine campagne, nos ex- portai ion» ayant en général renoncé à l’attitude expectative qu’ils avaient cru devoir adopter à («use de la situation locale et étant presque tous revenus à leur système des offres lernios. Cela facilitera certainement les choses, d si, comme on le prétend, il sera difficile de icnler l'Angleterre et l'Amérique, il n'en est jMt.s moins vrai qu'une partie du Continent se montre toujours disposée à acheter de nos cotons.

Espérons que le succès couronnerales efforts du commerce, lie fût ce que pour lui permettre le profiter des conditions auxquelles il peut acheter dans l'intérieur et qui lui laisseraient un énorme bénéfice. Les dernières affaires à notre conaissance conclu es avec lescultivateurs ont été faites à B. T. 15 au-dessus de» contrats, prix à fixer au plus tard en Janvier, avec I’. T. 50 d’avance par Cantor. C’est tout bonnement la manne pour celui (pii a de l'argent à employer dans ces sortes d’opérations.
1as avis au sujet de là récolte chez lions ne cessent d’être merveilleux. Souhaitons simplement que ce sera le cas jusqu’au bout.

De l'Amérique, au contraire, on se plaint cl ou a l'air de craindre sérieusement les effets •le la sécheresse, qui est encore partielle, mais qui pourrait s’étendre. Il est vrai que les baisser», par la bouche de Prico, leur chef de file, parlent maintenant de 13 1/2 à 14 millions de balles, après qu’il avait osé il y a deux mois àpeine lancer le chiffre maximum do 11 1/2 dans les meilleures conditions possibles jusqu’à la fin, mais cela n’empêche [MIS pour le moment les cours de progresser! Price prétend aujourd'hui que les plus excessives de Mai et de Juin qu'il n'avait cessé jadis de luxer de destructives pour la récolte, ont constitué dans le sol une réserve d’humidité qui pormet à la plante de résister aux diets do la s'elieresso! Nous savions bien qu’on serait venu à cela et nous l'avons dit dans nos revues de Mai !.' Et dire qno l'on paie'de l’argent chez nous pour se In ire câbler dos nouvelles par New-York pour être renseigné sur la réalité. C’est tout simplement absurde que de se faire gruger de la sorte par un pays où l'on est arrivé à considérer la divulgation des secret» par les fonctionnaires connue de simples infractions aux règlements !
Notre marché du disponible a été à peu près nul, tellement les affaires ont été insignifiantes. Du reste,/il n’en saurait être autrement avec la pénurie du choix à la fin de la campagne.
liant aux prix, ils sont fermes et la cote officielle de en matin n été maintenue au même niveau que lo-semainc passée sur tonte la ligue. Le disponible n'a plus lien à faire avec le terme.

Les exportations, comme dit pins liant, ont dépassé toute attente avec leur total de 91-1! Balles, contre 44(10 Balles environ pour 19(i. Il est vrai que de nouveau on soutient que la diminution sera des pim*sensible» pour la semaine prochaine. Tout est possible et la première journée avec ses 300 Balles d'embarquements n'annonce rien de brillant, mais (pii saurait atlirmer quoi (pie ce suit I Pour lu période correspondante en 1906 nous avons eu 4,000 balles. Comme position statistique, on relève du Bulletin do la Produce Association que le stock a fini par tomber à 29,000 Cantars au-dessous de celui de l'année dernière, tandis que certaines ]iersoniies .soutiennent que cela u'ést pas réellement le cas et (pie les rectifications de fin d’année en plus seront plus fortes (pic l'année passée. 11 serait oiseux de discuter sur une chose qui sera officiellement constatée dans une quinzaine de jours ; mois même si cela est le cos,, il ii'on est pas moins vrai, au dire des exportateurs, que nos ressources visibles actuelles sont presque enti-'reiuent engagées pour la filature ot qu’un stock avec quelques milliers de Cantars en plus ou en moins ne signifie absolument rien. Ijcs 7.000.000 ont été absorbés et voilà tout. '

Liverpool a été actif pour les égyptiens disponibles, mais comme prix, lè spot a perdu 1/1G h la cote de 10 3/4 et les futurs Août 2;64 air cours de 10 42/64. Les américains ont aussi eu des ventes assez copieuses pour la saison, tandis que comme cotations o’est la hausse qui s’est affirmée : Elle est de 18 points pour le spot coté h 7.40 de 16 et 20 pointa pour les futurs que nous trouvons respectivement à 6.93 l’Août.Sep- teuibre et 6.71 pour le Janvier-Février.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Il y a bien eu de 5 à 6,000 ardehs d'arrivages pendant la semaine,- mais il y en avait si peu à la vente que les allaires sont restées absolument nûlles pour ainsi dire. Aussi la cote de P.T. 80 pour le spot (pie l’on s’est plu à donner depuis trois ou quatre jours, u'est-elle en réalité que nominale on imaginaire.

Pour ce qui est de» contrat», nous en .sommes toujours à la même chanson : Rares affaires, mais manque do vendeurs aussi et hausse comme conséquence. lie dernier cours de l’Août ipii soi J. dit en passant, se trouve en de bonnes mains, est de P.T. 841.
Hull paie £8 5/- et très probablement avancerait si on lui tirait la corde, surtout s’il existe encore de petits besoins à couvrir comme cela semble être le cas. ,

Quant à la nouvelle récolto, il y a fermeté, mais pas de hausse et'pas d’entrain, ni ici, ni dehors Nos cours sont de P.T. 72 pour les 3 mois, tandis (pie Hull cote le Novembre- Janvier entre £ 7 1/3 et £ 7 2/6.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Samedi et lundi étant jours de fête à Londres, ou s’est empressé de chômer ici nii tout est prétexte au ilolce far niait'-.

On fait d'ailleurs si peu de chose-en ce' temps de vacances que nous ne songeons nullement à incriminer notre comité de l’association des courtiers en valeurs pour avoir saisi cette occasion de se reimser. Le marché a ouvort mardi faible et en baisse et l'impression a été plutôt défavorable, pondant la plus grande partie de la séance. Vers la fin, toutefois, une amélioration s’est produite, particulièrement sur les valeurs dirigeantes, et c’est on définitive nvcc une hausse sur l'ensemble de 1a cote qu'on a clôturé. La note dominante de la journée n été, cela se conçoit* l'indécision en l’absence de toutes nouvelles de Londres, (pii chômait depuis samedi. Quant aux affaires, elles ont été olairse- mées et c'est plutôt à un retour de la derannde qu’on n dû la petite reprise de la clôture qu’à des transaction» effectives Le lendemain, Londres étant arrivé soutenu, notre Corbeille a ouvert ferme et animée. *Toute la séance a d’ailleurs été remarquablement tenue, excepté vers la fin .où une légère réaction s'est produite à la suite d’ordres de vente provenant du Caire. L'ensemble de la cote n’en a pas moins fini phis haut comme la veille, mais comme la veille aussi les échanges n’ont guère été nombreux II n’y avait pas d’offres et l’on comprend que dans do toiles circonstances les haussiers avaient beau jeu pour pousser les cours à peu de frais. Hier, après une ouverture ferme, le marché a un peu réactionné pour reprendre en fin de séance ot clôturer sensiblement au même niveau que mercredi. Comme d'ordinaire, les affaires ont été clairsemées. Devant l’impuissance des haussiers a déterminer une amélioration rapide et suivie, il faut bien reconnaître que les vendeurs existent, mais (pie, retenus par l’espérance de plus liants cours en présence du mouvement actuel, ils poussent eux-mêmes ft la roue tant qu'ils peuvent tout en se délinrrnssaiit d’une partie de leur stock au fur et à mesure que l’occasion s’en présente. Et comme il existe des acquéreurs occasionnels, cela explique comment notre corbeille avec mie apparence Imussièro et animée ne traite qno fort peu d’affaires. Nos agents et spéculateurs se «ont, en effet, rendu cempte de l’inutilité de casser les cours pour écouler quelques titres. Plus habiles que naguère, au lieu d’ofl’rir tous à la fois leur marchandise, ils attendent tout simplement qu’on la leur demande. Il faut dire (pie lu détente leur permet, en ce moment de temporiser, ce (pii n’était pas le. cas lors do la récente d- bAcle. Aujourd'hui enfin la séance a été un digne couronnement de la semaine, en ce sens que la cote a continué sa marche ascensionnelle mais que les transactions n'ont augmenté ni en nonibre ni en importance. Cette fermeté n’en est pas moins remarquable, si l’on veut bien noter quo les cours des Valeurs égyptiennes nous sont - arrivés en laisse de Londres, que le taux privé d’escompte a encore haussé de 1/4 à 4% et que hier on a enregistré A New-York la plus forte baisse das valeurs qui ait été constatée depuis le krach du mois de mars dernier

. Sur une soixantaine de valeurs inscrites à la coto officielle de la Bourse d’Alexandrie, trente sont en hausse et dix seulement ou baisse, les autres demeurant stationnaires. Parmi les lluctimtions les plus sensibles, il faut signaler à la hausse, 15 fr. sur les Dividendes Tramways d'Alexandrie à 305, 8 fr. sur la Cassa di Sconto à 42, et 3/4 de livre sur les Nungovich Hotels à 18 8/4, et à la baisse 15 fr. sur les Privilégiées Bière d’Alexandrie à 160. La National Bank gagne 3/8 à 20 1.4,laRamIeh 1/4 à 4 3/4, les Privilégiées Tramways 4 fr. à 141 1/2, la Béhéra 1/4 do livre à 20 1/4, ainsi que la Deferred Delta à 9, la Delta Land 11/32 à 2 1/32, la Land Bank 5/1G à 7 5/16, les Estates 7/32 à 27/32, le Comptoir 1/4 à 3 l'ancienne et 2 15/16 la nouvelle, et l’Allotiuçut 1/4 l'aqtûm-è-2 3/8 et 25 P.T. ln part de fondateurs à 75. La reprise des Tramways est attribuée à des ordres d’achat provenant de Belgique et celle de la Land Bank à des ordres de Paris. En oe qui conoeme les autres, il s’agit en général d’une demande localo. Eu hausse - encore l’Agricole de 8 Vie à 8 1/8, les Jouissances Eaux du Caire det 182 à 183, les Markets de 27/6 à 27/9, la Sait and Soda de 17/6 à 18/G, les LotsTurcs.de 162 à 165, l'Investment de 1/2 à 9/16, l’Urbaine de -’1/1C à 3 3/4, l’Union Foncière de 4 9/16“ '4 5/8, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 à 4 3/16,la Banque d’Oricnt de 11G à 118, las Cotton 'Jinnersde 1 1/4 à 1 5.-16, la Levant de 9/16 à 19/32, l’United de 3/8 à 13/32 l’action et de 2 1.4 à

2 3/8 la part de fondateur, ' les Ritz de 11/16 h 23/32 et l’Helouan de 3/16 à 1/4. Le» Dividendes Bière d'Alexandrie fléchissent, au contraire, de 90 à 87, les Bières du Caire de 90 à 87 les Privilégiées et de37 à 35 les Dividende», l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 304 à 303 l’ancienne et de 262 à 260 la nouvelle, les Sucre- rias de 35 à 30, l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail do 22 à 21/9, la Building Lands de 2 7/16 à 2 1/4 et le Banco di Iloma de 105 à 104. Les cours des valeurs égyptiennes à Londres restent sans changement, excepté ceux de la National Bank qui progresse de 19 3/4 à 20 et de la New l)aïm qui fléchit de 13 à 12 3/4. Les demandes en numéraire se taisant de jour en jour plus pressantes, le taux privé d’escompte'vient d’être élevé en deux reprises de

3 3/4 à 4 0/0. D’untre part, le Consolidé An glais tombe de.82 7/8 à 81 7/8, niveau le plu» bas qui ait été atteint depui ; plus d'un demi- siècle. La proportion de la ré;:ic've de la Banque d’Angleterre avec ses engagements reste stationnaire à 46 7/8 %. A Paris, la Rente Française gngno 5 centimes à 95.12 et. le Crédit Foncier 3 fr.. à 688, ainsi que la Land Bank à 187: le Crédit Franco-Egyptien s’avance de 105.50 à 106. Ce sont là (les résultats peu brillants dans leur ensemble et. qui ne suffisent pas à justifier la hausse dont bénéficient actuellement ici les valeurs égyptiennes. Il nous semble qu'après avoir lougtemi» suivi la direction des marchés européens, notre place choisit bien mal son moment pour prendre la tête du mouvomont Nous n'en souhaitons pas moins que son initiative soit couronnée de succès. _

Tout l’avenir du marché dépendant de l’ai- sance future du numéraire, il ne faut pas oublier que les points noirs (pii ont déterminé la récente débftclo n’ont pas encore disparu de l'horizon. Loin de là. L’Amérique donne do nouvelles inquiétudes : on viont d’enregistrer à New-York, comme nous le disons pins haut, la plus forte baisse constatée-depuis le mois de mars dernier. H est donc probable que Wall- Street va de nouveau attirer chez lui l’or anglais, dans des proportions inquiétautes pour l’avenir. L’Egypte qui est à la veille d’opérer un drainage pareil pour sa récolte cotonnière verra de ce fait le taux de ses emprunta augmenté d’autant. Qui noos assure dans ces circonstances,que le marcjié des valeurs disposera des sommes dont il a besoin ou s’il en dispose que l’intérêt prélevé par los banques et les reports à payer ne constitueront pas nue .spéculation ruineuse et par suite inabordable 1

Si tel doit être le cas, les capitalistes ferpnt bien de no s’engager qu’à bon' esoieqt.jpof}»;,. éviter des méprisas comme celle du printemps, dernier. Il ne manque pas en Égypte des pi*; cements plu» sûrs et à la fois plus, rémunérateurs que ceux offerts par la spéculation, upe fois qu’ils sont grevés d’intérêts ou de rè]portyj .. monstrueux, avec de gentils égorgernéUta on perspective.

C’est à dessein que nous revenons là-dessus, car voici rétabli le fameux marché à terme qui par son organisation défectueuse nous a conduit k l'impasse où nous nous trouvons actuellement L’attrait irrésistible qu'exerce sur l'élément spéculatif local tout ce qui touche aux jeux de bourse fait.prévoir de façon à peu près certaine qu’il se laissera de nouveau entraîner à des excès,si des mesurés de précaution ne sont j>n.s prises et un oontrôle établi. Noqs souhaitons, tans trop l'errer, que les ooœités des bourses d’Alexàndne et du Caire feront, -, leur devoir sur. ce point et nous épargneront une nouvelle crise.

Nous ne pouvons pas terminer cette ohton^/ que sans dire un mot de I4 Bourse & Banking (Arrtiti) qui forme l’objet de tontes les conversations. A la suite i/e la décision prise, sur la proposition du comité, à l’assemblée extraordinaire de l’association des courtiers en valeurs d’Alexandrie, le comité a publié de nombreux avis pour presser l'exécution de la délibération votée. Ce qu’il y a de curieux, c’est qu'il exige du courtier, avant de lui payer les différences qui lui reviennent., la signature d'une formule où il est dit "Four solde etc." Ce qui si gnifie probablement que le courtier adé. renoncer à tonte réclamation ultérieure. Tour la livraison des titres qui a commencé. hie£ la société fait également signer aux malheureux souscripteurs une antre formule spécifiant.^üe 1 le signataire déclare »e soumettje’à tontes décisions éventuelles de l'as»opiàti^ii! Cè^te seconde formule doit être sigtiée par '.lejwùs- cripteur et par un témoin. Ajhntons t)Ue bhâur coup ont obtempéré aux conditions thi Wifcfyé, lys uns par complaisance et les auttar à causa de l’insignifiance des intérêts qu’ils ont j l’affaire. Mais il nous revient que les princij intéressés persistent à exiger qu’on Riifré procédure régulière et qu’on leur livre leunt différences et leurs titres 'sans formule, qu’ils se réservent tous leurs droits à l’ohcQiittô de la société, représenta par son éonseÜ Administration.

div.head: “INVESTMENTS.”
div.p:
“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
“Investments” (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning “Egyptian Gazette.”
LONDON & PARIS EXCHANGE LIMITED, GENERAL BANKERS. BASILDON HOUSE, BANK, LONDON, E.C.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Vendredi 9 Août Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres est renseigné en nouvelle hausse de 1/8 iV 4 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de 3/4 à8 17/8. L’Unifiée s’est maintenue jt 101 1/2. La National Bank est restée ferme à 20, TAgriooleà 8 1/8 et la Delta Light à 10. IS Daïra Sanieh a pordu 1/4 à 12 3/4. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a haussé de 3 francs à 687 et les Lots Turcs de 1 franc à 168. La Banque d’Athènes est restée invariée k 112.

Ici, la séance de ce mat'.n a été une des meilleures que nous ayons vues depuis fort longtemps. An'début, on se tAtait un peu pour connaître la tendance qui prévaudrait, et. dès qu’il fut avéré que les acheteurs étaient tris nombreux, les vendeurs se firent très rares, de sorte que forte est la proportion d’ordres qui ne purent être exécutés. Comme conséquence, la cote s’est inscrite en hausse 'dans tous les compartimenta.

L’activité tris nourrie s’est portée principalement sur les valeurs purement locales, délaissant les gras titree, ce qui est d’un bon augure, ces derniers ayant opéré leurs reprises il y a quelque temps déjà, alors que les autres restaient dans le marasme. Cette altemanco est préférable, car elle rend palpable la logique de la reprise &laquelle nous assistons. Ajoutons que les huissiers ont dû rononcer à pour Buivre leurs efforts et se inetfte à la hausse ainsi que nous le faisions entendre hier.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National Bank est en bonne’ tendance à 20 1/4- 5/16. L'Agricole est réalisée à 8 1/16. Le Comptoir Financier et Commercial parait en meilleure disposition à 3 1/16. lies fondateurs Société Générale sont recherchées à 37. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire haussent à 189. La Daïra Sanieh est inscrite à 12 8/4- 18/16 sans affaires. Los obligations anciennes Crédit Foncier sont lourdes a 303 et les nouvelles à 258. L’Allotmcnt est ferme h 2 3/8, sa part recule à P.T. 67. lies Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux sont en forte demande à 2 7/16 et leur part s’inscrit en hausse A P.T. 40 après avoir atteint 44. lies fondateurs Héliopolis sont à 12. La Brasserie des Pyramides se relève A «5 et les Automobiles-à 2 3/4.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, la tendance est excellente. Les Baehler haussent à 5 7/1C et lee Nungovich à 14. Les Upper Egypt sont mieux tenus A 2 3/413/16 et les Ritx calmes A 0 11/16 8/4. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates montent à 0 18/16 et leur part à 4. Les Constructions B6 relèvent A 01/2 et les Abdy à 0 5/8. • Les marché des valeurs étant fermé las samedis pondant la saison d’été, le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire ne paraîtra que le lundi 12 Août courant,

Examinant les chances d’une reprise sur les marchés européens, un journal belge opine pour l'affirmative et le démontre par les observations suivantes : “Ce qui tend à confirmer l'opinion d'après laquelle le plus fort de la crise serait passé, c’est que les banques semblent réussir d’une façon satisfaisante dans leurs efforts àdiminuer leurs engagements tout en fortifiant leur encaisse. C’est le cas notamment pour la Banque d'Angleterre, la Banque de Franco, la Rciolis- bank allemande,la Banque Impériale do Russie, dont le ohiffre des billets émis, qui est resté fixé durant plusieurs années A 1,200 millions de ronblee,vient d'être réduit A 1,190 millions, concurremment avec une augmentation de l'or en caisse et en dépôt à l’étranger

“ De plus les demandes de crédits tendent d'elles-mêmes à s’atténuer. Evidemment, le marché mondial n’est jamais complètement soustrait aux émissions actuelles ou en perspective. L’heure présente compte donc & UBsi ses candidats emprunteere. Pourtant, il est indéniable qu/k l’hésitation des capitalistes correspond ane>éaçrve presque égale des emprunteurs. Oeux-ci, en présence des conditions particulièrement loimleSr^jssues de l'état du marché, cherchent à éviter autant que possible de devoir contracter de nouveaux engagements, en limitant leurs besoins. “L’impression qui se dégage de tout cela, c’est que nous assistons à un travail de reconstitution leste mais progressive. Il est à coup sûr probable, oertain même, que ce travqjl sera musqué momentanément par des causes do raréfaction occasionnelles, car il se présente tou- joure des besoins immédiats tels que vacances, récoltes, liquidations mensuelles et le reste. N’empêche qu'uno attitude d’abstention, fût- elle relative et forcée, ne peut manquer, en définitive, de produire ses effets. .“Pratiquement, cela revient. à dire qu’ils nous semblent être mal inspirés ceux,qui; attirés par le rendement plus élevé des dépflls en banque, laissent leur argent sans emploi direct C'est en ces temps de prostration financière qu'il faut surtout avoir le courage et l’initiative de chercher à ses capitaux un placement à la fois solide et rémunérateur. Faute de quoi, les occasions passent ; on s’en apercevra -quand il sera trop tard."

Hier a eu lieu ressemblée de la Corporation des agents de change du Caife, dans le but do discuter les conditions de rétablissement du marché à terme. Un projet de règlement avait été préparé par les Roins du Comité et n servi de base à la discussion. Les points saillants du nouveau règlement, sont les suivants : Etablissement d'une “Chambre de compensation” dont nous avons parlé hier ; Marge obligatoire A verser par le client, dont le 50% devra être déposé par l’agent à la Chambre de compensation ; Classement des titres en trois catégories suivant lesquelles la marge obligatoire sera plus ou moins élevée; Apposition d’un timbre sur les factures moyennant une taxe de 1 millième. Une nouvelle nssemblée aura lieu mardi prochain 13 courant k l'effet de délibérer sur quelques modifications de détail.

div.head: SHIPPING MOVEMENTS
div.p: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: Notice to Advertisers
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the Gazette from advertisers direct.

div.head: Sudan Government
div.p: NOTICE.

Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in the presence of an official or other reliable witness.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the Egyptian Gazette is published at midday everyday Saturday in the time for the Austraian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhanutive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton need and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of precedingday, complete tubular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc. etc.,Subscriptions for year P.T. 100 in Egypt for abroad the postage. For further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
